facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 23 of 1965 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 23 of 1965. Appeal by special leave

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated July 17, 1964 of Patna High Court in Criminal Revision No. 597 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 17, 1964- of the Patna High Court in Criminal Revision No. 597 of 1963. Nur-ud-din Ahmed and D. Goburdhan, for the

facts.text: Patna High Court judgment dated July 17, 1964 set aside acquittal ordered by 1st Additional Sessions Judge, Gaya and directed retrial of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal against the judgment. July 17, 1963. of a learned single Judge of the High Court at Patna setting aside the acquittal of the appellant ordered by the 1 st Additional Sessions Judge. Gaya and directing his retrial.

facts.text: Appellant tried on charge under s.302 IPC for intentionally causing death of Kuldip Singh with firearm on December 18, 1961 in village Gajra Chatar.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was tried on three charges levelled against him First was under s. 302 of the Indian Penal Code for intentionally causing the death of one Kuldip Singh with a fire-arm on December 18, 1961 in village Gajra Chatar the second

facts.text: Appellant charged with attempt to murder Sarju Singh by shooting at him with the same weapon.

anchor.surface_text: second was attempt murder Kuldip Shighs companypanion Sarju Singh by shooting at him with the same weapon and the third was the unlawful possession of the weapon  a revolver  which is an offence under the Arms Act.

facts.text: Appellant charged with unlawful possession of revolver under Arms Act.

anchor.surface_text: and the third was the unlawful possession of the weapon  a revolver  which is an offence under the Arms Act. It appears that there was some iII-feeling between the appellant and Kuldip Singh,

facts.text: Ill-feeling between appellant and Kuldip Singh due to appellant conducting cases for his sister in litigation started by Kuldip Singh over possession of land.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that there was some iII-feeling between the appellant and Kuldip Singh, number directly, but because the appellant, who is a lawyer, was companyducting cases on behalf of his sister in prolonged litigation started by Kuldip Singh and his party.The litigation companycerned the possession of land

facts.text: All cases in litigation ended in favour of appellant's sister, admitted before Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The litigation companycerned the possession of land and it is admitted before us that all the cases had in fact ended in favour of the appellants sister.

facts.text: Occurrence took place during inquiry under s.107 CrPC where notice issued to Kuldip Singh's party to show cause and furnish interim bail.

anchor.surface_text: The occurrence is stated to have taken place when an inquiry into a case under s. 107 of the Code of Criminal Procedure was taking place. A numberice had been issued to Kuldip Singhs party to show cause why they should number be proceeded against and asked to furnish interim bail.

facts.text: Kuldip Singh accompanied by Sarju Singh and Musafir Singh (PW12) proceeding towards village Nawadah via Tilaiya Railway Station on morning of incident.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution story is that the deceased Kuldip Singh accompanied by Sarju Singh the injured man, and one Musafir Singh  P. W. 12  were proceeding towards village Nawadah via Tilaiya Railway Station. They had started early in the morning and had taken an hour and a half to reach village Gajra Chatar where the incident is said to have taken place.

facts.text: Prosecution witnesses found two persons sitting under a tree near garden in Gajra Chatar, recognised appellant and one unknown person.

anchor.surface_text: When they reached near a garden. they found two persons sitting under a tree and approaching them they recognised the appellant but the other was unknown. These persons began to shadow Kuldip Singh and his companypanions, and after they had proceeded a little further towards the garden,

facts.text: One person fired at Kuldip Singh on his back, prosecution case identifies appellant as shooter with revolver.

anchor.surface_text: one of them fired at Kuldip on his back. The prosecution case is that Sarju immediately turned round and attempted to catch hold of the appellant who had fired with a revolver, but the appellant shot Sarju on his leg behind the knee. Thereafter. the appellant and his companypanion ran away.

facts.text: Appellant shot Sarju Singh on his leg behind the knee after Sarju turned to catch him.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution case is that Sarju immediately turned round and attempted to catch hold of the appellant who had fired with a revolver, but the appellant shot Sarju on his leg behind the knee. Thereafter. the appellant and his companypanion ran away.

facts.text: Kuldip Singh made report of incident naming appellant, lost consciousness.

anchor.surface_text: The report of the incident was made by Kuldip Singh himself who seems number to have lost his companysciousness and in that report he named the appellant. Subsequently, Kuldip made two dying declarations in which he again named the appellant as the assailant.

facts.text: Kuldip Singh made two dying declarations naming appellant as assailant with revolver.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently, Kuldip made two dying declarations in which he again named the appellant as the assailant. describing the weapon of attack as a revolver. Kuldip died and the case was started against the appellant as stated already.

facts.text: 1st Additional Sessions Judge, Gaya acquitted appellant after finding evidence unsatisfactory.

anchor.surface_text: The, learned Sessions Judge on an appraisal of the evidence found it unsatisfactory. He began by stating that the medical evidence as also the evidence of the ballistic expert  P.W. 17  clearly disclosed that the assault was number companymitted with a revol vet but with a shot gun.

facts.text: Sessions Judge found medical and ballistic evidence (PW17) showed assault with shot gun, not revolver.

anchor.surface_text: He began by stating that the medical evidence as also the evidence of the ballistic expert  P.W. 17  clearly disclosed that the assault was number companymitted with a revol vet but with a shot gun. He also companyld number believe the evidence. that Sarju companyld be shot from behind when he was grappling with the appellant.

facts.text: Sessions Judge disbelieved evidence that Sarju was shot from behind while grappling with appellant.

anchor.surface_text: He also companyld number believe the evidence. that Sarju companyld be shot from behind when he was grappling with the appellant. He felt that this created doubt as to whether the injured persons and Musafir who all companysistently described the weapon as a revolver had in fact been able to see the weapon or to identify the assailant.

facts.text: Sessions Judge found prosecution case not free from concoction, gave benefit of doubt to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Having found this unworthy of credit, the learned Sessions Judge went into a number of other circumstances which in his opinion tended to show that the prosecution case was number free from companycoction and hence number free from doubt. He felt that the attack was from an ambush and the deceased and 1he witnesses had named the appellant with whom they had deep enmity but they had number seen the real assailant.

facts.text: Patna High Court in revision questioned findings of Sessions Judge, reinterpreted evidence, ordered retrial.

anchor.surface_text: In revision, the learned Judge in the High Court went into the evidence very minutely. He questioned every single finding of the learned Sessions Judge and gave his own interpretation of the evidence and the inferences to be drawn from it. He discounted the theory that the weapon of attack was a revolver and suggested that it might have been a shot gun or companyntry made pistol

facts.text: High Court found only error in Sessions Judge judgment was remark about cross-examining defence witnesses with police statements.

anchor.surface_text: The only error of law which the learned Judge found in the Sessions Judges judgment was a remark by the Sessions Judge that the defence witnesses who were examined by the police before they were brought as defence witnesses ought to have been cross examined with reference to their previous statements recorded by the police, which obviously is against the provisions of the Code.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Patna High Court erred in exercising revisional powers under s.439 CrPC against acquittal by private party revision.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the learned Judge was clearly in error in proceeding as he did in a revision filed by a private party. against the acquittal reached in 1he Court of Session. The practice on the subject has been stated by this Court on more than one occasion.

facts.text: Supreme Court restored acquittal by Sessions Judge, set aside High Court order for retrial.

anchor.surface_text: Looking to all the circumstances that have been brought to our numberice, we are satisfied that the Sessions Judge acted within his rights in deciding the case which to us appears also to be somewhat doubtful in many respects and the High Court was therefore in error

facts.text: Revision filed by private party, not Government appeal.

anchor.surface_text: This we do number companyceive to be his duty in dealing in revision with an acquittal when Government has number chosen to file an appeal against it.

under s. 439 of the Code of Criminal Procedure acted in accordance with the principles settled by this Court for interference with acquittal by way of revision filed by a private party.

concepts.interpretation: High Court cannot reweigh evidence or substitute its view in revision against acquittal filed by private party; limited to manifest illegality, gross miscarriage of justice, or glaring procedural defects.

precedents.citation: Logendranath Jha and others v. Shri Polailal Biswas 1

anchor.surface_text: Logendranath Jha and others v. Shri Polailal Biswas 1 , this Court points out that the High Court is entitled in revision to set aside an acquittal if there is an error on a point of law or no appraisal of the evidence at all. This Court observes that it is not sufficient to say that the judgment under revision is perverse or lacking in true correct perspective.

precedents.case_name: Logendranath Jha and others v. Shri Polailal Biswas
precedents.cited_proposition: High Court cannot set aside acquittal in revision merely because judgment is perverse or lacking perspective; error on point of law or no appraisal of evidence required; retrial loads dice against accused

precedents.citation: K. Chinnaswamy Reddy v. State of Andhra Pradesh 2

anchor.surface_text: K. Chinnaswamy Reddy v. precedents.case_name: K. Chinnaswamy Reddy v. State of Andhra Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: Interference in revision with acquittal only for glaring procedural defects like lack of jurisdiction, shutting out admissible evidence, considering inadmissible evidence, or overlooking evidence; list not exhaustive but defects must be analogous
